abstract.p: Addition of natural inorganic nanotubes to epoxy acrylate resin can significantly improve their mechanical properties. Halloysite nanotubes are one kind of novel reinforcing and toughening materials for polymers. In the present work, halloysite nanotubes were compounded to epoxy acrylate resin to improve the wear resistance and toughness of the composites. To improve the embedding of halloysite nanotubes within the epoxy acrylate resin matrix, the halloysite nanotubes surface was grafted by poly (methyl methacrylate). The morphology of the grafted halloysite nanotubes particles demonstrates a core-shell structure with halloysite nanotubes as the core and the grafted polymer as the shell. Poly (methyl methacrylate) was chemically attached to the halloysite nanotubes particles as indicated by the Fourier transform infrared and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy results. The poly (methyl methacrylate) grafted halloysite nanotubes (poly (methyl methacrylate)-g-halloysite nanotubes) then compounded with epoxy acrylate resin and composites are formed via ultraviolet-curing method. The hardness, flexibility, impact resistance and wear resistance of epoxy acrylate/poly (methyl methacrylate)-g-halloysite nanotubes composites were markedly improved in comparison with that of neat epoxy acrylate. The improvement was correlated to the well-dispersed halloysite nanotubes and the interfacial bonding between epoxy acrylate resin and poly (methyl methacrylate)-g-halloysite nanotubes. The well dispersion of halloysite nanotubes in the matrix is attributed to the modification on the surface of halloysite nanotubes.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Ultraviolet (UV)-curable composites offer considerable attention for the rapid and solvent-free curing of coating films.1–3 Hybrid organic-inorganic composites have received significant interest in recent years due to their superior mechanical properties and improvement in scratch and abrasion resistance in coating applications.4 Fillers, such as silica,5–8 carbon nanotubes (CNTs),9–12 clay layer,13–16 zinc oxide,17,18 zirconia19,20 and titanium dioxide,21 have been recently used in UV curable composites to improve the mechanical properties of coatings, especially hardness and wear resistance.22–25 The modification of the fillers surface can offer superior performance, improved dispersibility and increased compatibility of fillers in the matrix.26,27 Due to the surface modification of silica, UV-curable acrylate formulations show markedly improved properties as compared to neat polymers, e.g. increased hardness and modulus, improved scratch and abrasion resistance, higher gas barriers and temperature resistance.28–30 It was investigated that with the addition of only 0.025 wt% of CNTs into the UV-curable epoxy resin, a highly crosslinked epoxy network was obtained, characterized by a high gel content and good mechanical properties.11,31 Composites filled with CNTs show a significant improvement in their mechanical and thermal properties.32

Halloysite nanotubes (HNTs), as a two-layered aluminosilicate with a chemical composition similar to kaolin, have a predominantly hollow tubular structure. For their economical accessibility, high mechanical strength and biocompatibility, HNTs have been widely used in controlled or sustained release, in nanoreactors or nanotemplates, for the elimination of contaminants or pollutants and fabricating high performance polymer composites.33

It is well-known that the dispersion state of the filler and the interfacial properties are two critical factors in determining the ultimate performance of the polymer composites.34–36 For their large surface area (∼60 m2 g−1), HNTs can hardly be effective reinforcement of polymers because of the agglomeration and the unsatisfied interfacial bonding in the polymer matrix.37 Furthermore, surface modifications on HNTs may prevent particles from agglomeration and provide a good compatibility toward polymers.38 The significantly mechanical improvements were correlated to the improved HNTs dispersion and strengthened interfacial interactions.39–41

In contrast with other nano-sized inorganic ﬁllers, HNTs are readily obtainable and are much cheaper than other nanoparticles, such as CNTs. Given the tubular morphology and geometrical similarity between HNTs and carbon nanotubes (CNTs),42 HNTs may have the potential to provide cheap alternatives to the expensive CNTs.33,43 The present study focuses on the HNTs functionalization for improved dispersion and interfacial interactions with polymer resins. In this study, HNTs grafted with poly (methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) was conducted to obtain HNTs/epoxy acrylate composites. The effects of functionalization were studied on the HNTs dispersion, wettability with polymer matrix and the properties of HNTs/epoxy acrylate composites. The wear performance and toughness behind the improved properties of composites using functionalized HNTs were specifically studied.

sec.title: Materials and preparation
sec.p: HNTs were mined from Hubei province, China, and purified according to the reported procedure.19 Methyl methacrylate (MMA) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd, China, and distilled under reduced pressure at 5 mmHg. Azo-bis-isobutryonitrile (AIBN) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd, China, and recrystallized from ethanol prior to use. Isopropanol, chloroform and all other chemicals were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd and dried over 4 Å sieves for 24 h before use. Methacryloxypropyltrimethoxysilane (MPS) was purchased from Dow Corning Co. Ltd and used as received. Bisphenol A epoxy methacrylate (EB605) were purchased from UCB Co. Ltd and used without further purification. The photoinitiators 1-hydroxycyclohexyl benzophenone (Irgacure-184) was purchased from Ciba Co. Ltd, Switzerland.

First, the surface of HNTs was functionalized with MPS. In a typical experiment, 10.0 g HNTs was added in solution (5.0 g MPS dissolved in 100.0 ml toluene); the reaction lasted for 12 h under stirring and refluxing. Then the suspension was filtered using a PTFE membrane with a pore size of 0.22 µm by using a large amount of toluene to wash off the unreacted reagents. Finally, the solids MPS-HNTs were obtained after vacuum drying at 60℃ for 24 h. After being treated with MPS, 5.0 g MPS-HNTs, 5.0 g MMA and 50 mL isopropanol were added into a 150-mL three-necked flask and then ultrasonicated for 30 min under nitrogen atmosphere. AIBN was dissolved and added into the aforementioned suspension with stirring and at refluxed. After a reaction for another 12 h, the suspension was cooled down by ice water and poured into large methanol to precipitate the final crude product. The grafted products were washed several times with methanol, and then the products were dried at 60℃ for 24 h under vacuum. Exact weight of the above product was extracted with chloroform in a Soxhlets extractor for 72 h to remove PMMA homopolymer. The pure homopolymers were dried at 60℃ for 24 h vacuum. The amount of polymer grafted onto the HNTs surface was determined by weight loss when were heated to 600℃ by a thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The percentage of grafting and its efficiency of polymer on to the surface were calculated by the following equations.44 (1)Grafting (%)=m1/m2×100% (2)Grafting efficiency (%)=m1/m3×100% where m1 (g) is the weight of polymer grafted onto HNTs, m2 (g) is the weight of HNTs and m3 (g) is the total weight of polymers.

After epoxy acrylate resin was mixed with PMMA-g-HNTs and ultrasonicated for 30 min, the photo-initiator (Irgacure-184) was added and treated with ultrasonication for 5 min. Note that during the preparation light exposure was avoided. At all times, samples were not exposed to light. After a degassing under reduced pressure, the above liquid resin was dropped onto glass plates or tinplates. The thickness of resultant films of composites were controlled about 20 µm. Samples were cured with the UV lamp (1 kW) for 30 sec.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained from a Bruker Vertex 70 FTIR spectrometer (Bruker, Germany). The spectrum was scanned 16 times at a resolution of 4 cm−1 from 4000 cm−1 to 400 cm−1.

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of the HNTs, MPS-g-HNTs and PMMA-g-HNTs were recorded using a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD; Kratos Analytical, Eppstein, Germany. A monochromated aluminum Kα source (1486.6 eV) was used. All core level spectra were referenced to the C 1 s neutral carbon peak at 285.0 eV.
TGA was performed on a TA Q5000 instrument under nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10℃ min−1 from 30 to 600℃.

The contact angles of HNTs thin films were measured to investigate the changes in surface energy and wettability with the epoxy acrylate resin (EB 605). Powder of HNTs and PMMA-g-HNTs were placed in a vacuum oven for 5 h at 80℃ and then molded to thin films with diameter of 20 mm and thick of 1 mm. The thin films appeared smooth when inspected by optical microscopy. Static contact angles of the HNTs films were measured on a Drop Shape Analysis System DSA100 (Krüss GmbH, Hamburg, Germany) at 20℃. At least five measurements were made for each sample, and the average values were used to calculate the surface energy of HNTs films. For each measurement, the volume of liquid droplet was 4 µL, except epoxy acrylate which was 10 µL. The contact angles were calculated by software according to the Laplace-Young model. The correlation between surface energy and contact angle (θ) can be expressed by the Young’s equation45: (3)γLS=γS-γLcosθ where γS, γL and γLS are the surface energies of solid, liquid and solid–liquid interface, respectively. The surface energy consists of two components, namely the polar (γp) and dispersive (γd) components. These components can be determined based on the harmonic mean method as expressed in46,47 (4)γLS=γL+γS-4(γLp×γSpγLp+γSp+γLd×γSdγLd+γSd)

The work of adhesion (Wa) is calculated in this approach from the Dupré-Young equation48: (5)Wa=γL(1+cosθ) If two liquids with known components of surface energies were used in the contact angle measurements, the corresponding solid and solid–liquid surface energies, i.e. γS and γLS, can be determined. Water and glycerol were employed as liquids, and the two components of surface energy are 50.7 and 22.1 mJ m−2 for water and 30.0 and 34.0 mJ m−2 for glycerol, respectively.45 The surface tension components of epoxy acrylate resin used in this study is calculated using a Drop volume tensiometer TVT 2 (LAUDA, Germany) and the value is 48.0 mJ m−2.

The morphologies of HNTs and PMMA-g-HNTs were examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis on a JEOL JEM-2010HR. The samples were prepared from acetone dispersion of the HNTs or PMMA-g-HNTs (0.1 g in 50 mL), which were sonicated for 30 min and then deposited carbon film supported by copper grids.

The abrasion resistance of composites was measured with an Abrasion Tester JM-IV (Tianjin Jinke Chemical Industry Machinery Co., China) according to ASTM D4060. The sample was fabricated on a glass plate. Two CS-10 wheels with a 250 g load on each one were loaded onto the sample surface. The plate rotated at a speed of 60 r/min. The taber index is the weight loss after 1000 cycles. The tests were performed at temperature at 25℃ ± 2℃ and relative humidity 50% ± 5%.

Unlubricated sliding wear tests were carried out on a MXD-01 sled for coefficient of friction tester (Labthink Instruments Co., China) using a moving sled with a stationary plane according to ASTM 1894. The weight of sled is 200 g and the driver speed is 100 mm min−1, the gliding distance is 60 mm. The specimens for tests were machined with contact area of about 63 mm × 63 mm. The specimens were attached on the sled by 3 M double-coated tape. The plane was covered with 3 M™ Wetordry™ Paper Sheet 734 P400, and the paper sheet was used only one time. The static and dynamic friction coefficients of composites were obtained using the MXD measurement and evaluation software. The tests were performed at temperature of 25℃ ± 2℃ and relative humidity 50% ± 5%.

The pencil hardness was measured using a pencil hardness tester with the pencil at an angle of 45° under a 1-kg loading according to ASTM D3363. The pencil used in this experiment was made by China First Pencil Company Ltd. The lead of the pencil was ground perpendicularly to give the lead of the pencil an angle of 90 before measuring the pencil hardness each time. The tests were performed at temperature of 25℃ ± 2℃ and relative humidity 50% ± 5%.

The flexibility was measured according to ASTM D4338 with an YZQ-II cylindrical mandrel bend tester (Shanghai Pushen Chemical Industry Machinery Co., China). The smaller value means the better flexibility. The flexibility is the best when the number is 1 mm. The tests were performed at temperature of 25℃ ± 2℃ and relative humidity 50% ± 5%.

The impact resistance of the composites was determined through falling weight direct impact testing according to ASTM D2794 with the falling weight of 1000 g and impact hammer diameter of 8 mm by using a CJQ-II impact tester (Shanghai Pushen Chemical Industry Machinery Co., China), according to the ASTM D2794. The starting height was increased until the composite was damaged, and the maximum height at which the film was intact was recorded. The tests were performed at temperature of 25℃ ± 2℃ and relative humidity 50% ± 5%.

The roughness of the composites was performed using a BMT Expert3D analyzer. The 3D surface topography of the samples was recorded on the basis of the white-light interference theory. The scanning area for all the samples is 4 × 3 mm. The scanning point density was 300 point/mm. The average roughness for all the samples was obtained using the BMT measurement and evaluation software. The tests were performed at temperature of 25℃ ± 2℃ and relative humidity 50% ± 5%.

The morphology of the fracture surfaces and worn surfaces of the composites were coated with gold and observed using the field emission scanning electron microscopy (Nova nano SEM 430, FEI, Netherlands).

The specimens of composites were ultramicrotomed into thin pieces of about 120 nm in thickness with Leica EMUC6 and the sections were supported by holey carbon film on Cu-grids. The transition electron microscopy (TEM) observations were done using a Philips Tecnai 12 TEM (Eindhoven, Netherlands) with an accelerating voltage of 30 kV.

sec.title: Characterization of PMMA-g-HNTs
sec.p:
FTIR and XPS measurements have been performed on HNTs and PMMA-g-HNTs. Figure 1 displays the FTIR spectra of HNTs, MPS-HNTs and PMMA-g-HNTs. FTIR spectra of MPS-HNTs exhibit new absorption peaks at 1720 cm−1 (–C = O) and 2953 cm−1 (–C–H). Furthermore, the peaks of –OH stretching band at 3703 cm−1 and 3628 cm−1 become weaker, since hydroxyl groups on the surface of HNTs has been partially reacted with methoxy groups of MPS. In FTIR spectra of PMMA-g-HNTs, the C–H stretching vibration (2953 cm−1) and C=O vibration (1732 cm−1), the –CH3 bending bonds (1393 cm−1) and the –C(O)–O–C stretching (1244 cm−1–1153 cm−1) indicate the successful grafting onto HNTs. Figure 2 shows the survey XPS spectra of HNTs, MPS-HNTs and PMMA-g-HNTs, the surface element contents of C and O increase and that of Si and Al decrease after the PMMA had been grafted (Table 1). In the high resolution XPS spectrum of C 1s for PMMA-g-HNTs, three peak components at 284.6, 285.9 and 288.6 eV were assigned to C–C, C–O and C=O, respectively. The FTIR and XPS results show that PMMA has been covalently grafted onto the surfaces of HNTs. Figure 1.

The percentage of grafting and its efficiency of polymer onto the surface of HNTs can be calculated by TGA result. Figure 3 shows the thermogravimetric curves of HNTs, MPS-HNTs and PMMA-g-HNTs after extraction by chloroform for 72 h. It is observed that the grafted polymer begins to decompose at about 250℃ and ends at 500℃, which ascertains that polymer is bonding onto the HNTs surfaces. The percentage of grafting and grafting efficiency is 11.4% and 17.8%, respectively. Figure 3.

The morphology of HNTs and PMMA-g-HNTs is compared using TEM observation. It can be seen that the surface of the HNTs is rather smooth with a tube diameter of about 50 nm (Figure 4(a) and (b)). As shown in Figure 4(c) and (d), it is clearly indicated that the surface of PMMA-g-HNTs is coated by a polymer layer (about 2–5 nm thick), showing a rougher surface. The morphology of the PMMA-g-HNTs demonstrate a core-shell structure with HNTs as the core and polymeric as the shell. Therefore, we can conclude that the PMMA are grafted onto the HNTs. Figure 4.

sec.title: Surface energies and wettability of HNTs with epoxy acrylate
sec.p:
The static contact angles of different liquids on HNTs films are summarized in Table 2. The hydrophobicity enhances substantially after PMMA grafting as indicated by the significant increase in contact angle from 11.7° to 67.0° when water is used. A similar trend is also observed when the contact angle is measured using glycerol as a droplet. The surface energy of HNTs is calculated from the contact angles values according to equation (3). The total surface energy (γs), dispersive components (γsd) and polar components (γsp) of different HNTs are summarized in Table 3. The total surface energy of HNTs measured here was 71.4 mJ m−2, after grafting, the surface energy of HNTs decrease by more than 42%, and the reduction mainly from the decrease in polar component of HNTs (from 53.0 to 20.6 mJ m−2), while the dispersive component of surface energy is essentially unchanged. As a consequence, PMMA-g-HNTs are expected to have more conspicuous hydrophobicity and the lower surface energy weaken the fillers agglomerating force. The contact angles of epoxy acrylate resin on the HNTs films are measured to evaluate the interfacial interactions between the HNTs and epoxy acrylate monomer. As shown in Table 2, the contact angle of HNTs decreased from 118.9° to 68.5° after PMMA grafting, suggesting improvement of wettability between the HNTs and epoxy acrylate. The works of adhesion of HNTs-epoxy acrylate interface (Wa) are calculated based on equation (5). The surface and interface properties of different HNTs are summarized in Table 4. Works of adhesion between fillers and epoxy acrylate increase from 24.8 mJ m−2 to 65.6 mJ m−2 after PMMA graft, verifying the effectiveness of grafting in enhancing the interfacial interactions between the fillers and polymer matrix. Interfacial shear strength (IFSS) is an important mechanical parameter to characterize the adhesion strength between fillers and polymer matrix.49,50 The results of interfacial adhesion were generally consistent with the thermodynamic work of adhesion (Wa).51–53 According to Braithwaite et al.54 and Sun et al.,55 (6)τ=(EmEf)1/2Waλ where τ and Wa denote the IFSS and the work of adhesion, Em and Ef are the moduli of the matrix and filler, respectively, and λ is the equilibrium interatomic distance at the interface between matrix and filler. The work of adhesion between PMMA-g-HNTs and epoxy acrylate was higher than that of HNTs between epoxy acrylate, indicating that the more stable mechanical adhesion and more effective stress transferring mechanism works at the interface in PMMA-g-HNTs/epoxy acrylate composites. sec.title: Mechanical properties of epoxy acrylate composites
sec.p:
Table 5 shows the effect of content of PMMA-g-HNTs on the mechanical properties of epoxy acrylate composites. Pencil hardness test is a standard industrial method to roughly evaluate the short-term scratch resistance of the coatings.56–58 As seen in Table 5, the pencil hardness shows continuous improvement with increasing PMMA-g-HNTs content. The pencil hardness has the most improvement to three higher grades till 5 wt% PMMA-g-HNTs content. This improvement of pencil hardness is due to the hard PMMA-g-HNTs that can probably in part migrate toward the surface of the composites. The increase of hardness is always related to an increase on scratch and abrasion resistance.59 Interestingly, the impact resistance of composites has largely increased by about 150%. This improvement is comparable to the toughening effect of polyurethane,60 and HNT toughening was achieved at a lower filler content. For the current epoxy acrylate composites, the flexibility of composites even has increased slightly by incorporating HNTs. Table 5.

sec.title: Morphology of epoxy acrylate composites
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows the TEM photos of the epoxy acrylate composites. It can be seen that the PMMA-g-HNTs are dispersed in the matrix very uniformly. The individually separated nanotubes are found in the samples although aggregated nanotubes coexisted in the samples. The interfacial cracking between the nanotubes and the matrix is also observed. The cracks appeared during the observation of the morphology of the hybrids under the high accelerating voltage used in the microscopy. The nanoscale cracks observed in the TEM experiment may be attributed to the good interfacial bonding in the hybrids matrix.61 The organic matrix has much higher shrinkage compared with HNTs. As a consequence, the strong interfacial bonding between the matrix and HNTs leads to cracking when the thin film is exposed to an electron beam. Figure 5.
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) photos of epoxy acrylate composites: (a) 1 wt% PMMA-g-HNTs; (b) 2.5 wt% PMMA-g-HNTs (black arrows represented the microcracks). HNT: Halloysite nanotube; PMMA: poly (methyl methacrylate).

Increases in fracture toughness of halloysite–epoxy composites are mainly due to mechanisms such as crack bridging, crack deflection and plastic deformation of the epoxy around the HNTs clusters.38,42 To investigate the toughening mechanisms, the fracture surfaces of the broken specimens after the impact tests were examined using a field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM). As seen in Figure 6(a) and (b), the fracture surface of neat resin is rather smooth and shows typical characteristics of brittle fracture. In stark contrast, the fracture surface of composites blended with PMMA-g-HNTs is relatively rougher. From the micrograph in Figure 6(c) and (d), the PMMA-g-HNTs delay the crack initiation or hindering the crack propagation by deflection, blocking or crack bridging. The PMMA-g-HNTs bridging as shown in Figure 6(c) (for crack initiation region and crack propagation region) is well in agreement with the reported mechanisms like CNT-bridging.39 The nanotubes debonding phenomenon appears at the matrix yield stress and permits the release of internal stresses by nanotube sliding through the matrix. As mentioned above, the PMMA-g-HNTs play an important role in stopping the running crack, which dissipate tremendous fracture energy and lead to enhancement in impact resistance of the epoxy acrylate composites. Figure 6.
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) micrographs of the fracture surface of (a) neat epoxy acrylate resin, (b)–(d) epoxy acrylate composites containing 2.5 wt% PMMA-g-HNTs. HNT: Halloysite nanotube; PMMA: poly (methyl methacrylate).

sec.title: Tribological performance of epoxy acrylate composites
sec.p:
Effect of the content of PMMA-g-HNTs on the wear volume and friction coefficient of the epoxy acrylate composites sliding against the abrading wheels is revealed in Figure 7(a) and (b) under dry sliding. Within the entire range of filler content, both wear volume and frictional coefficient of the composites incorporated with PMMA-g-HNTs show a drastic decrease as compared with that of the neat epoxy acrylate resin. The wear volume of epoxy acrylate composites decreases from 80 × 10−4 cm−3 to 13 × 10−4 cm−3 by the addition of 1 wt% PMMA-g-HNTs. With a further increased concentration of PMMA-g-HNTs, both the wear volume and the friction coefficient increase slightly. It might be due to agglomeration introduced by overloading of the filler.62 So, it is of high importance that the PMMA-g-HNTs are uniformly dispersed rather than being agglomerated in order to yield a good property profile. Figure 7.
Effect of PMMA-g-HNTs on the (a) wear volume, (b) friction coefficient and (c) roughness of epoxy acrylate composites. HNT: Halloysite nanotube; PMMA: poly (methyl methacrylate).

The root mean square roughness and average roughness for the epoxy acrylate composites with various PMMA-g-HNTs content are shown in Figure 7(c), indicating that the worn surface of epoxy acrylate composites are much smoother than that of neat epoxy acrylate resin. Clearly, the wear process in the PMMA-g-HNTs filled composites is dominated by polishing and the worn pin surface appears rather smooth. It means that the friction surface is relatively homogeneous, which aspect with stabilized sliding conditions and low coefficients of friction. The increase in toughness may be due to the agglomerates in the composites.

For investigation into the wear mechanism, the morphologies of worn surface for pure epoxy acrylate resin and epoxy acrylate composites filled with 1 wt% PMMA-g-HNTs are characterized by an FESEM (shown in Figure 8). The corresponding surface of neat epoxy acrylate resin is rather rough, displaying plucked and ploughed marks. The wear scars on the epoxy pin are characterized by obvious scale-like traces. This is indicative for fatigue-delamination generated under repeated loading during sliding. This rough worn surface reflects that pure epoxy acrylate resin has poor wear resistance against its counterpart and displays the features of adhesion and abrasive wear mechanism. For filled composites, the worn surface is smoother, and only a small amount of scratches can be found on the surface. This phenomenon corresponds to the improved wear resistance of epoxy acrylate composites. Furthermore, the worn surfaces of PMMA-g-HNTs filled epoxy acrylate composites only show the traces of mild wear, evidencing that in this case the fine wear debris acts as a lubricant and contributes to materials removal by polishing.63 For an improvement of the wear resistance, various kinds of fillers, e.g., TiO2, ZrO2, SiC, carbon fibers, carbon nanotubes, were incorporated into different polymer matrices, e.g., epoxy resin64, polyetheretherketone (PEEK)65 and polyamide (PA).66 The improvements of the wear resistance were due to either mechanical or chemical reasons. The mechanical reasons include the enhanced modulus and hardness practically. The chemical reasons involved the improved bonding between transfer films and metallic counterparts.67 In this case, the prominent wear mechanisms in dry sliding may be attributed to the following factors. First, the incorporation of PMMA-g-HNTs in epoxy acrylate resin leads to considerably increase the mechanical properties of the composites. Second, the PMMA-g-HNTs can be considered as a three-body abrasive. According to previous reports, addition of hard fillers in polymer components normally results in the improvement of the wear resistance.68 During sliding, the PMMA-g-HNTs serve as fundamental load-bearing elements in the wear process of polymer composites, reducing the shear stress. And the enhancing filler-polymer interfacial interaction protected the PMMA-g-HNTs lasting in the matrix, which improves the wear resistance of composites. Third, during the course of friction and wear, PMMA-g-HNTs dispersed uniformly in the epoxy acrylate composites may be released from the composites and might be transferred to the contact zone of epoxy acrylate composites and the counter faces. This transfer is due to the adhesion and interlocking of the polymer fragments into counter asperities during sliding.69 Thus, PMMA-g-HNTs may serve as spacers preventing the close touch between the counter face and the composites block, which contribute to restrain the scuffing and adhesion of the epoxy acrylate composites under dry sliding against the counter faces, that is, reducing friction and wear rate of the epoxy acrylate composites. sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Chemical grafting of PMMA onto the surface of HNTs is accomplished through in situ polymerization. The PMMA-g-HNTs is found to improve the basic mechanical performance of epoxy acrylate composites effectively, particularly toughness and wear resistance. Compared with the unfilled neat resin, the composites filled exhibited lower wear volume, friction coefficient and roughness. The pencil hardness has the most improvement to three higher grades till 5 wt% PMMA-g-HNTs content. The impact resistance of coatings has largely increased by about 150%. The impact resistance of composites with 2.5 wt% PMMA-g-HNTs is much higher than that of the cured neat resin. There were also noticeable enhancements in wear resistance. The wear volume of epoxy acrylate composites decreases from 80 × 10−4 cm−3 to 13 × 10−4 cm−3 by the addition of 1 wt% PMMA-g-HNTs. However, the friction and wear of the filled composites deteriorated with further increasing content of PMMA-g-HNTs. The remarkable effect of HNTs on the performance of composites was correlated with the surface grafting on HNTs.
